Q:
Our company has 6 computers connected by several communication links. These computers are named: Server Solarflare, Server Silverstream, Server Glacier, Server Emberfall, Server Ironclad and Server Willowbrook. 
To ensure network security, we need to install monitoring devices (such as firewalls or intrusion detection systems) on some of these computers so that all communication links are monitored. 
Assume that the connections between the computers (i.e., the communication links) are bidirectional. This means that information can flow in both directions across any link. Our goal is to deploy monitoring devices in a way that ensures all communication links are covered by at least one monitoring device. 
Problem: How can we select the minimum number of computers to deploy monitoring devices, such that every communication link is monitored by at least one device? 
Communication links as follows: : 
Server Solarflare is connected with Server Silverstream, Server Emberfall, Server Ironclad. 
Server Silverstream is connected with Server Emberfall, Server Willowbrook. 
Server Glacier is connected with Server Willowbrook. 
Server Emberfall is connected with Server Willowbrook.

Problem: How can we select the minimum number of computers to deploy monitoring devices, such that every communication link is monitored by at least one device? 
Communication links as follows: : 
Server Emberlight is connected with Server Thunderbolt, Server Windswept, Server Mirage. 
Server Darkhorse is connected with Server Thunderbolt, Server Mirage. 
Server Thunderbolt is connected with Server Stormcloud. 
Server Mirage is connected with Server Stormcloud.

Our company has 6 computers connected by several communication links. These computers are named: Server Vortex, Server Lighthouse, Server Amberwave, Server Bluewave, Server Blackwood and Server Silverhawk.

Our goal is to deploy monitoring devices in a way that ensures all communication links are covered by at least one monitoring device.
